snippet: In a blow to the White House’s strategy of minimal and indirect intervention in the Syrian conflict, Washington-backed secular rebel groups are lagging behind hard-line Islamists in weapons acquisition.
abstract: Classified assessments of the Syrian conflict indicate that most of the arms shipped at the behest of Saudi Arabia and Qatar to Syrian rebel groups are going to hard-line Islamic jihadists, and not to the more secular opposition groups the West wants to bolster; information casts into doubt whether the American strategy of minimal and indirect intervention in the Syrian conflict is accomplishing its intended purpose or is instead sowing the seeds of future insurgencies.

byline.contributor: Robert F. Worth and Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: In a blow to the White House’s strategy of minimal and indirect intervention in the Syrian conflict, Washington-backed secular rebel groups are lagging behind hard-line Islamists in weapons acquisition.

headline.seo: Jihadists Receiving Most Arms Sent to Syrian Rebels
headline.main: Rebel Arms Flow Is Said to Benefit Jihadists in Syria
headline.print_headline: Rebel Arms Flow Is Said to Benefit Jihadists in Syria

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
